entry.title: Joule Capability Documentation Chat
entry.content:
As use cases involving AI become increasingly intertwined with our lives, we have developed a documentation chat for ABAP developers. The documentation chat is available for you to ask questions and find solutions to any ABAP development problem you may have. The conversation with the documentation chat should help you solve your tasks and serve as your helpful guide.

In this blog, we explain the rationale behind the documentation chat, how to use it, and what it offers in SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2511.

 

Rationale

Our primary goal is to provide easy access to the ABAP Cloud product documentation and to enhance the accessibility and findability of our content. Finding documentation has always been an issue that’s often caused by missing semantics in the provided content. To address this issue, we employ retrieval-augmented generation to deliver relevant information in response to a query.

 

Using the Documentation Chat

The documentation chat is available as a Joule capability in ABAP development tools for Eclipse. For information about using Joule in ABAP development tools for Eclipse, refer to Opening the Joule Chat View.

To use the documentation chat, follow these steps:

  1. In the Joule view, select the button /.
  2. Choose docs.

    If you send the request without a prompt, you receive a description of the capability.
  3. Enter your question in the text area.

     



  4. Press Enter or select the Select message (Enter) button.

    You receive a response to your question. The answer can include text, bullet points, and code examples. Also, references are always provided, allowing you to view the source documentation and verify the given answer.

 

Supported Documentation

As of SAP BTP ABAP Environment 2511, the documentation chat includes the following documentation:

  • ABAP Keyword Documentation
  • ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model
  • ABAP Data Models
  • ABAP Cloud

When chatting with the documentation, you can expect assistance with the topics in the documentation above. It is also possible to ask follow-up questions after an initial question, as the chat history is respected.

In the coming releases, you can expect more to come. Feel free to leave a comment or a like.

entry.title: SAP BNAC as AAS Server: Driving Interoperability and Efficiency in Digital Twin Collaboration
entry.content:
SAP Business Network Asset Collaboration  (BNAC) is taking a major leap forward in enabling standardized, interoperable digital twin ecosystems. With its latest innovation, SAP BNAC now acts as an Asset Administration Shell (AAS) Server, supporting AAS APIs and delivering seamless integration across the value chain. This capability empowers OEMs, operators, and suppliers to exchange asset data efficiently, automate processes, and prepare for compliance with initiatives like the Digital Product Passport (DPP).

Why AAS Matters

The Asset Administration Shell (IEC 63278) is the Industry 4.0 standard for representing a digital twin of an asset—whether a component, machine, or plant. It structures master data, documentation, and operational data into Submodels (e.g., Digital Nameplate, Handover Documentation) and exposes them via standardized APIs. This eliminates custom integrations and ensures consistent semantics across partners.

By supporting AAS APIs, SAP BNAC becomes a native AAS Server in your digital twin landscape. This means:

  • Consume, create, and manage AAS content directly in SAP BNAC
  • Connect suppliers, OEMs, and operators using industry standards
  • Enable end-to-end collaboration without manual data translation

What’s New: SAP BNAC as AAS Server

With AAS API support, SAP BNAC offers:

  • Standardized AAS onboarding: Suppliers upload AAS and Submodels* via APIs.
  • Automated mapping: AAS elements are translated into SAP business objects (Model, Equipment, Documents).
  • Interoperability at scale: Connect with external AAS systems and ecosystems like Factory-X.

Note (*): Supported submodels (e.g., Digital Nameplate, Handover Documentation)

Key Use Cases

1) Streamlined Onboarding of Asset Data into Business Systems (import of AAS via AAS API)

Traditionally, AAS data was imported via file-based methods (read my previous article if you want to learn more on how SAP BNAC already support AASX import). Now, SAP BNAC enables API-based AAS import, streamlining collaboration between manufacturers and system integrators.

How it works:

  • A system integrator retrieves AAS and Submodels from suppliers via APIs to SAP BNAC as AAS Server.
  • SAP BNAC automatically creates corresponding business objects:
    • Model (AAS Type)
    • Equipment (AAS Instance)
    • Documents
  • Data syncs with SAP ERP for processes like purchase orders (**).

Note (**): SAP BNAC and SAP ERP requires initial configuration (mapping BNAC objects to existing ERP classes and characteristics)

Business Value:

  • Faster onboarding of component data (e.g., motors, controllers, valves).
  • Reduced manual effort and error-prone mapping.
  • Improved collaboration during asset definition.

2) End-to-End ERP–AAS Integration

Beyond import, SAP BNAC supports AAS export via AAS APIs, enabling organizations to share standardized digital twins derived from SAP ERP data.

How it works:

  • Materials and Equipment from SAP ERP are replicated in SAP BNAC.
  • Classified using Templates aligned with AAS Submodels (Digital Nameplate).
  • Exposed via AAS APIs for third-party systems.

Note: additional configuration and mapping between SAP ERP and SAP BNAC needed. Also, AAS and Submodels metadata (e.g., AAS id) must be added in SAP BNAC.

Business Value:

  • Out-of-the-box interoperability: AAS and Submodels like Digital Nameplate are derived out of ERP.
  • Enhanced transparency across the asset lifecycle.
  • Easier integration with 3rd party systems via AAS APIs.

Why This Matters for OEMs and Operators

  • Efficiency without custom integrations: Standards-based APIs reduce complexity and cost as well as make it easier to bring asset data into your business processes.
  • Rich collaboration: Access technical data, certificates, manuals, and more through AAS Submodels.
  • Future-proof: Prepare for DPP and Industry 4.0 ecosystems.

Getting Started

Explore:

  • SAP BNAC Product Documentation
  • AAS API Overview

Takeaways

SAP BNAC as AAS Server is more than a technical enhancement—it’s a strategic enabler for digital twin collaboration. By leveraging AAS standards, businesses can:

  • Automate asset data creation.
  • Accelerate supplier onboarding.
  • Ensure compliance and interoperability.
  • Unlock new value streams through richer networks and standardized data exchange.

What is next

What is next - our journey has just started. Our plan is support additional Submodels and ensure that you will be compliant with DPP and DPB. Got curious? Please reach out to us and be part of this journey!

entry.title: Large Cap Biopharma: 2024 Valuation Sensitivities
entry.content:
Pfizer: Valuation as a Reflection of Complexity

Pfizer is often discussed in the market through simplified narratives: post-pandemic normalization, patent expirations, or near-term earnings pressure. While each element matters, none is sufficient by itself to explain Pfizer’s performance, strategic positioning, or valuation.

Earlier this year, we developed a detailed analysis of Pfizer, including a Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) valuation model, to better understand the company’s potential for long-term value creation. A few months later, it is useful to step back and reflect on that analysis — not to revise conclusions, but to place them in a broader business context.

This note follows a bottom-up structure: starting with business and portfolio dynamics, moving through capital allocation and profitability, and only then connecting these elements to valuation and market pricing. While COVID-related effects remain part of the recent financial history, they are not the central driver of the long-term dynamics discussed here.

Pfizer operates one of the most complex business models in global healthcare. Its activities span research-intensive innovation, large-scale manufacturing, regulatory navigation, portfolio lifecycle management, and capital allocation across long time horizons. Even a simple snapshot of Pfizer in Q1 2025 illustrates how many moving parts must work together to sustain performance.

A Business Defined by Scale, Scope, and Long Cycles

Pfizer’s scale is both an advantage and a constraint. A broad portfolio across therapeutic areas and geographies provides diversification, global reach, and operational leverage. At the same time, scale introduces complexity:

  • long development timelines
  • staggered patent cliffs
  • heterogeneous market dynamics
  • continuous reinvestment requirements

Importantly, Pfizer is not a single-product or single-cycle company. Its economic profile reflects the aggregation of many medical solutions at different stages of maturity, each with distinct risk, return, and timing characteristics. As a result, short-term performance is an imperfect proxy for long-term value creation, particularly given long drug investment cycles.

Revenue Is Not a Single Trajectory

One recurring theme from the analysis is that Pfizer’s revenue profile cannot be understood as a linear trend. Revenue is shaped by several overlapping forces:

  • portfolio turnover as products mature and face loss of exclusivity
  • the timing and slope of pipeline launches
  • geographic mix and pricing dynamics
  • external shocks, normalization effects, and inorganic investments

Rather than viewing revenue volatility as a sign of instability, it is more accurate to see it as a structural feature of large-cap biopharma. The portfolio requires constant rebalancing as some drugs experience revenue decline and others take their place. The central question is not whether revenues fluctuate, but whether the organization can consistently replenish its portfolio.

When we zoom in on pre-LOE drugs, some high-revenue products already show signs of slowing or decline, while others continue to grow but approach patent expiration. This naturally raises the question: what happens to biopharma revenues before, during, and after LOE?

The answer depends on a nuanced interplay of internal actions and external factors — including lifecycle management strategies, competitive dynamics, and therapeutic alternatives. These factors can mean the difference between a steep revenue drop and a more controlled decline.

 

In practice, a large biopharma company such as Pfizer constantly experiences both growth and decline across its product portfolio.

While some drugs mature and slow down, others pick up and help sustain revenue continuity. In this sense, large biopharma resembles portfolio management: individual assets rise and fall, requiring ongoing reinvestment and reallocation rather than optimization of any single product.

Inorganic Portfolio Balancing

The need for continuous portfolio renewal naturally leads to a strategic choice: invest internally through R&D, or acquire external assets.

 

A review of Pfizer’s mergers, acquisitions, and divestitures shows a willingness to act decisively to maintain portfolio relevance. While the pricing of some acquisitions has been debated, the broader pattern is clear: inorganic actions play a central role in shaping portfolio maturity and future growth potential.

 

Capital Allocation Is Central to the Story

Decisions around internal R&D, acquisitions, divestitures, debt management, and shareholder returns collectively shape Pfizer’s risk profile and future earnings power.

Capital allocation at this scale is not about optimizing a single metric in a single year. It centers on balancing:

  • flexibility
  • resilience
  • long-term value creation

Over the last seven years, Pfizer has invested more than $70 billion through inorganic transactions — a magnitude comparable to its organic R&D spending. Beyond acquisition prices and divestiture proceeds, these transactions also carry ongoing costs, including post-merger integration and transition services (TSA).

Criticism around capital deployment often focuses on the argument that value erosion reflects overpayment for acquisitions. In support of this argument, current valuation multiples are often cited as the benchmarks for a fair acquisition consideration.

 

While this perspective deserves consideration, it is incomplete without examining Pfizer’s broader capital structure and working capital dynamics.

 

To fund both organic and inorganic investments — while maintaining dividend payments exceeding $9.5 billion in 2024 — Pfizer increased leverage. Total debt rose from approximately $35 billion at the beginning of 2023 to $71 billion a year later, before declining to $64 billion at the start of 2025. With equity of roughly $88 billion, the resulting debt-to-equity ratio stood near 72%.

 

Margins Reflect Strategic Choices, Not Just Efficiency

Operating margins can be scrutinized in isolation, but they reflect deliberate trade-offs. Investment in R&D, business development, manufacturing capabilities, tax optimization and commercial infrastructure all weigh on near-term margins while supporting long-term optionality.

 

Periods of margin compression often coincide with pipeline build-out or integration of acquired assets. Margin recovery, in turn, depends on successful execution and maturation of those investments.

Recognizing margin pressure, Pfizer launched a transformation program aimed at cost reduction. Reviewing this program alongside historical performance allows us to outline plausible ranges for future operating efficiency and margin expansion — not as guarantees, but as scenarios grounded in past behavior and structural constraints.

Key Model Assumptions

With revenue dynamics, profitability, and capital deployment established, we then turn to the DCF model.

Fully aware of LOE-related revenue risks, we conservatively project revenue growth of 1% per year over the next five years.

This leads to the following free cash flow components used in the valuation.

As a result, the full Free Cash Flow picture can be summarized as follows:

 

Estimating the Weighted Average Cost of Capital involves both financial analysis and judgment. Once WACC is established, we proceed to the full DCF framework, using both perpetuity growth and terminal EBITDA multiple approaches.

With the WACC estimated, we can proceed to the full DCF model which can be conceptually described as follows:

We utilize both Perpetuity Growth and Terminal Value EBITDA Multiple approaches to estimate Pfizer’s Enterprise Value on the basis of the above projected financials.

Valuation as an Output, Not an Assumption

While the resulting enterprise value and implied share price are informative, the sensitivity analysis is more revealing.

Given Pfizer’s transformation efforts following COVID-related normalization, the key question is not whether profitability can improve, but within what range such improvement might plausibly occur — and how markets might value that improvement.

We can visualize these plausible scenarios by examining a few parameters that affect enterprise value:

By examining a limited set of parameters that meaningfully affect enterprise value, we can explore scenarios such as:

  • Can Pfizer improve EBIT by 10%?
  • How might such improvement translate into shareholder value?

If operating gains materialize, the model suggests that valuation can respond meaningfully. However, capturing that value requires disciplined execution across all dimensions of the business:

  • portfolio execution with the revenue impact
  • cost discipline for profitability expansion
  • capital allocation including acquisition premium in line with the investor expectations
  • market confidence translating into COE and WACC

Enterprise Value Sensitivity Surface: A Landscape, Not a Point

Not all valuation drivers are within management’s control. Financial market expectations, interest rates, and macroeconomic conditions add further complexity.

The enterprise value sensitivity surface emphasizes this point by shifting the focus from precision to range. Different combinations of near-term growth and long-term assumptions can justify the same valuation outcome. Pfizer’s current valuation at almost $190bn EV sits closer to the conservative end of that landscape, reflecting restrained expectations for durability rather than skepticism about the underlying business.

Iso-valuation curves further highlight the trade-offs involved. Slower near-term growth can be offset by stronger long-term persistence, and vice versa. What matters is the combination of assumptions, not any single input.

 

Seen through this lens, Pfizer’s valuation reflects a market that is cautious about long-term convergence rather than skeptical of near-term economics.

Analyst Positioning Signals Patience, Not Negativity

Consensus analyst ratings reinforce this interpretation. A prevalence of “Hold” recommendations suggests caution rather than bearish conviction. The market appears to be waiting for clearer evidence on execution and durability before adjusting long-term expectations.

 

This positioning aligns with a company viewed as fundamentally sound, yet operating in an environment where confidence is rebuilt gradually.

Market Prices vs. Modeled Value

Comparing Pfizer’s historical share price with a model-implied value derived in early 2025 helps connect theory with market behavior. The modeled value serves as a stable reference point, while the actual share price fluctuates above and below it.

 

This comparison highlights an important distinction: valuation models estimate economic value, not the path markets take to reach it. Deviations reflect sentiment, timing, and confidence rather than immediate changes in intrinsic worth.

The divergence observed into late 2025 underscores how markets often require tangible proof of recovery and durability before re-rating, even when valuation frameworks remain intact.

The gaps between market price and modeled value are best viewed as expressions of risk perception. Periods below the valuation anchor correspond to elevated uncertainty and higher discount rates, not necessarily to impaired fundamentals.

From this perspective, Pfizer’s valuation reflects a cautious, evidence-driven market — not a rejection of long-term potential.

Bringing the Story Together

Taken together, this bottom-up analysis suggests that Pfizer’s valuation reflects complexity, long cycles, and conservative market expectations rather than a simple judgment on quality or strategy.

The appearance of undervaluation does not stem from a single mispricing, but from how markets process uncertainty, time, and execution risk. As these uncertainties resolve, valuation is likely to evolve gradually rather than abruptly.

This framework does not argue for an immediate re-rating or a specific price target. Instead, it offers a disciplined way to understand how business fundamentals, strategic decisions, and market psychology interact over time.

In that sense, valuation is not the conclusion of the analysis — it is the lens through which Pfizer’s broader business story is reflected. We plan to revisit this framework once full 2025 financial results become available.

entry.title: SAP CPQ - Headless Configurator (Configurations v2 API)
entry.content:
What is the Headless Configurator?

The Headless Configurator decouples the user interface from the configuration engine. Instead of relying on SAP CPQ’s native UI, external applications—such as eCommerce sites, dealer portals, mobile apps, or kiosks—can call SAP CPQ’s Configuration V2 API to handle all configuration logic, rules, and pricing in real time.

This means:

  • Your front-end remains lightweight and fully customizable.
  • SAP CPQ continues to be the single source of truth for product rules and pricing.
  • No duplication of logic across channels.

How It Works

  1. Create Configuration
    External systems initiate a configuration session by calling the Create Configuration endpoint with product and context parameters (Market, Pricebook, Currency, Effective Date, Business Partners).

  2. Dynamic Updates
    Every attribute change triggers a Patch Configuration call. SAP CPQ responds with updated valid values, rule messages, and pricing deltas—ensuring guided selling and compliance.

  3. Finalize and Order
    Once configuration is complete, the external system retrieves the final configuration and either:

    • Places the order directly in ERP, S/4 HANA or S/4 HANA Public Cloud or
    • Creates a quote in SAP CPQ for sales-assisted workflows.

Primary Use Cases

  1. 3rd‑party eCommerce: A modern online shopping interface with a dynamic product configurator and real-time pricing updates in the cart.
  2. Reseller/Dealer Portal: A professional dashboard with tailored product variants and pricebook context, emphasizing collaboration and customization.
  3. Self‑Service Web/Mobile: An enterprise buyer using a tablet to configure complex assets independently, with an option to escalate to sales.
  4. Embedded Apps: A field technician at a kiosk using a lightweight app with SAP CPQ rules and pricing integrated seamlessly.
    The scene should feature a clean, high-tech aesthetic with glowing UI elements, holographic screens, and a connected network theme. Use vibrant colors like blue, teal, and white to convey trust, innovation, and transparency. Include subtle SAP branding elements without overpowering the design. Style: ultra-realistic with a touch of futuristic minimalism.

Why It Matters

The Configuration V2 API is more than a technical upgrade—it’s a strategic enabler for omnichannel selling, digital transformation, and partner ecosystem growth. By centralizing configuration intelligence in SAP CPQ and exposing it headlessly, businesses can innovate faster, reduce risk, and deliver consistent, guided experiences everywhere.

E2E Flow — Anonymous eCommerce (configure → order)

 

E2E Flow — Dealer Portal (configure → sales‑assist → quote/order)

Next Steps

Ready to unlock the power of headless configuration? Explore SAP CPQ’s API documentation or reach out to me SAP CPQ Solution Architect to learn how Configuration V2 can fit into your digital strategy.

API Documentation : Configurations v2 API

Create configuration: 

POST /api/configuration/v2/configurations
{
  "ProductSystemId": "LAPTOP-PRO-15",
  "Context": {
    "MarketCode": "US",
    "PricebookCode": "B2C",
    "CurrencyCode": "USD",
    "EffectiveDate": "2025-10-16",
    "InvolvedParties": [{ "Key": "SoldTo", "ExternalId": "CUST-123" }],
    "ExtensionFields": [{ "Name": "Channel", "Value": "WebshopA" }]
  }
}

 Get configuration: 

GET /api/configuration/v2/configurations/{configurationId}?$select=attributes,values,pricingDetails
Accept-Language: de-DE

 Patch configuration: 

PATCH /api/configuration/v2/configurations/{configurationId}
{
  "Attributes": [
    { "Id": 1001, "Values": [{ "Id": 9001, "IsSelected": true }] }
  ]
}

Delete configuration:

DELETE /api/configuration/v2/configurations/{configurationId}

Note: Not allowed if configuration is attached to a quote item.

entry.title: Hedonic Pricing: What Do Investors Pay For?
entry.content:
Executive summary
Investors do not primarily pay for short-term margin spikes or isolated growth initiatives.  Instead, over a 35-year horizon, the market has consistently rewarded one thing above all else: persistency.  This is the term Goldman Sachs attaches to the capital structure discipline, specifically leverage (Assets/Equity).  We find that leverage explains the majority of the variation in Home Depot’s Market Cap / Equity, our proxy for the Price/Book ratio.  This finding closely replicates Goldman Sachs’ famous analysis of what markets pay for, but applies to a single company and validates using long-horizon time-series data. Profitability and efficiency matter — but they come second.

This note describes our findings in three simple blocks:

  • data preparation and transformation
  • results and interpretation
  • what it means for Home Depot and investors.

 

1. Data preparation: looking at Home Depot the way markets do

This analysis starts from a simple premise:

If we want to understand how investors value Home Depot, we must model Home Depot the way investors observe it.

We assembled 144 quarters (1990–2025 YTD) of data covering both market valuation metrics (P/B ratio, Market Cap, Enterprise Value) and accounting fundamentals (assets, equity, leverage, margins, asset turnover).

This is important: unlike cross-sectional studies across many firms, this model is time-series for a single company. We are not asking why Home Depot is valued differently than Lowe’s.  We are asking a more precise question:

What has historically driven changes in Home Depot’s valuation over time?

Log transformations: elasticity, not levels

All core variables are expressed in logarithmic form. This is essential for interpretation:

  • Coefficients become elasticities
  • Relationships become scale-free
  • Long-term growth dynamics dominate short-term noise

In plain English: we are modeling percentage changes investors respond to, not absolute dollar movements.

The dependent (predicted) variable is the

ln(Market Cap / Equity), a proxy for the P/B ratio, directly links market valuation to balance-sheet fundamentals — exactly how long-term equity investors think.

Three independent (predictor) variables are

Leverage = (Assets - Goodwill) / Stockholders Equity where we specifically remove Goodwill to account for “tangible leverage” only,

Net Margin = Net Income / Revenue, 

Turnover = Revenue / (Assets - Goodwill) here too, assets are net of goodwill for "tangible turnover."

In one quarter, Home Depot reported negative net income. In 9 quarters the company reported negative equity - initially in 2019 as a result of the adoption of the FASB ASU No. 2016-02, "Leases (Topic 842)".  This is why the lines in the plot below exhibit discontinuities: natural logarithm of a negative number is undefined.

In log terms, valuation and operating fundamentals move in clear and persistent co-movement over time.  Sustained multiple expansion coincides with rising operating efficiency, greater leverage capacity, and improving margins, while periods of valuation compression align with broad-based fundamental deterioration.  Valuation itself behaves as a slow-moving state variable, reflecting investors’ long-run assessment of economic capacity, whereas operating metrics adjust at higher frequency around that state.  Even during externally imposed disruptions—such as recessions and market panics—temporary dislocations give way to re-convergence, underscoring that market multiples are ultimately disciplined by fundamentals rather than driven by sentiment alone.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This systematic co-movement directly motivates a hedonic valuation, in which observed market multiples are modeled as the equilibrium price investors assign to distinct operating characteristics rather than as standalone time-series outcomes.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 

2. The hedonic pricing regression: what explains Home Depot's valuation?

Conceptually, the model mirrors the DuPont identity, which decomposes Return on Equity into three elements:

  • Leverage (Assets / Equity)
  • Profitability (Net Margin)
  • Efficiency (Asset Turnover)

Our model - with the log-transformed data - is:

To accommodate periods of negative net margin and negative stockholders’ equity, we introduced dummy variables that flag sign changes (0 for positive values, 1 for negative).  The inclusion of dummy variables allows the model to accommodate sign changes without materially altering coefficient magnitudes or inference. 

The regression, run in R Studio, produced a formula where most coefficients are statistically significant at the 5% level (p<0.05).  The ln_net_margin variable returned a p-value of 0.0744, indicating a 7.4% probability of observing this result (or one more extreme) if there were actually no relationship between ln_net_margin and ln_mktcap_over_equity.

We drop the decimals:

Here is the most intuitive interpretation of the model’s coefficients and log-terms: elasticity. These bars represent standardized coefficients, not raw elasticities, and are intended for relative magnitude and intuition, not literal percentage translation.


 

Home Depot’s valuation is most sensitive to changes in asset turnover, indicating that improvements in capital efficiency drive market multiples more powerfully than margin expansion alone.

In raw log terms, leverage can be interpreted as follows: a 1% increase in leverage increases Market Cap / Equity by approximately 1%.

Net margins exhibit a comparatively modest elasticity, suggesting that accounting profitability, while important, does not independently command valuation premiums.

Taken together, the results align closely with how long-term equity investors think: sustainable valuation expansion is rooted in efficient deployment of capital, not short-term margin optimization.

 

The key result: persistency dominates

The model has R2 of 94.05% and Adjusted R2 of 93.91%.  If we decompose the individual predictors’ contribution to this explained variance in Market Cap/Equity, the key conclusion emerges:

Visually, this is striking: the largest block by far is leverage. Most of what investors paid for Home Depot over 35 years is captured by three variables of which Leverage is the most significant. This is what Goldman Sachs found in their panel data analysis calling the hedonic pricing element persistency.

Persistency, in Goldman’s framework, means:

  • Stable capital structure
  • Predictable balance-sheet scaling
  • Consistency in how equity is multiplied into assets and cash flows

What we have done here is replicate that insight, but:

  • For one company
  • Using 35 years of quarterly data
  • With a fully transparent regression framework

The alignment is almost exact.

Notably, the model contains no explicit time trends, macroeconomic variables, or sentiment indicators—yet it explains over 94% of valuation variation, underscoring how consistently markets price the same economic fundamentals.

In Home Depot’s case, leverage alone explains roughly two-thirds of the market’s valuation signal. Profitability matters — but it is secondary, less persistent, and less trusted by investors as a long-term signal.

Both actual and predicted series represent the log market-cap-to-equity multiple where

The chart shows that a simple three-variable hedonic model tracks Home Depot’s valuation remarkably well over more than three decades. Even though the model has no awareness of time, cycles, or sentiment, its predicted valuation closely follows the actual market valuation across multiple regimes. Deviations between the two lines are concentrated in periods of market stress or speculative excess, while long-run trends are captured cleanly.

In other words, investors consistently price the same economic fundamentals, though they might temporarily lose discipline during panics and recessions.

This directly supports the executive intuition captured in the quote by Dilip Shanghvi, the founder and CEO of Sun Pharmaceuticals:

“I will never risk capital; but I will risk profit.”

Markets agree.

 

3. How solid is our model? Is it "too clean"?

No serious business model should avoid this question.

Residual behavior (what we checked)

We explicitly reviewed:

  • Residual distribution
  • Residuals vs. fitted values
  • Time clustering during stress periods

 

 


 


 

With F-statistics 684.4 on 3 and 130 degrees of freedom and p-value < 2.2 x 10-16, the model is structurally sound, though markets still panic occasionally — and then revert.

That is exactly what we would expect from real investors.

What do residuals tell us

Residuals widen during periods of macro-financial stress, including the Global Financial Crisis, COVID, and the post-2022 rate shock. This is expected: markets temporarily price fear, liquidity constraints, and narrative risk beyond firm-level fundamentals.

Outside stress regimes, residuals oscillate tightly around zero with no persistent bias. Deviations cluster in time rather than by sign, indicating regime effects rather than model misspecification. Overvaluation episodes—most notably the late 1990s—mean-revert as market discipline reasserts itself.

Bottom line: the model “fails” when markets panic — and reliably re-anchors valuation once sentiment normalizes.

 

*   *   *

 

So, what does this actually mean for Home Depot?

Insight #1: capital discipline is the valuation anchor

Home Depot’s high valuation multiple is not fragile.  It is anchored in:

  • Consistent leverage
  • Predictable scaling of equity
  • Transparent capital return policy

Any unexpected shift in capital structure — aggressive deleveraging or sudden debt expansion — would matter far more to valuation than a bad margin quarter.

Insight #2: profitability matters — but only if it is repeatable

Operational improvements (margin, turnover, ROA) explain about one quarter of valuation variation.  That is meaningful — but markets discount one-off wins.  Investors prefer:

  • Incremental improvements
  • Predictable execution
  • Fewer surprises

Spectacular quarters impress analysts. Consistent ones move valuation.

Insight #3: macro matters less than headlines suggest

Despite constant focus on rates, housing cycles, and sentiment, macro variables explain only a single-digit share of long-term valuation variation.  Home Depot’s valuation history is fundamentally a company-driven story, not a macro-driven one.

Once full-year 2025 financials are available, we will:

  • Re-estimate the model
  • Test coefficient stability
  • Re-evaluate valuation implications under the new regime and compare/contrast the hedonic pricing model with the traditional DCF valuation model

If history is any guide, the conclusion is unlikely to change — but the path may.

 

Final thought

Markets are often accused of being short-term and irrational. Over 35 years of Home Depot data suggests the opposite.

Investors are remarkably consistent in what they reward.

They pay for persistency.

entry.title: RANDOM FOREST ITERATION 1
entry.content:
DATA COLLECTION AND PREPARATION

  1. First, we collected approximately 12 years of available daily stock data, for a total of 3,091 observations:
  2. Then we created additional measurements “gauges” such as RSI and MACD.
    • Relative Strength Index (RSI from 0 to 100) measures strength and speed for stock price changes.  Interpretation: RSI above 70 is commonly interpreted as overbought and historically associated with increased risk of pullbacks (leading to lower stock price).
    • Moving Average Convergence / Divergence (MACD) captures changes in momentum by comparing short- and long-term exponential moving averages.
  3. Next step included running a few raw data plots to visually check the data.  Of course, we first split the stock prices data set 80/20 into training (blue line) and testing (red line). The numbers are in Vietnamese dong. ($1 USD ~ 26,300 VND).  Obviously, the data is split chronologically, so that 80% training set is the oldest data and 20% validation is the newest.

RStudio is the statistical platform to perform these analyses and random forest predictions.

Daily returns (stock price on day 2 / stock price on day 1) are not quite normally distributed so we take a note of this for subsequent improvements (iteration 2):

 

TREE SELECTION AND PRUNING

Although the random forest model used in this analysis is globally nonlinear, at any given day the next-day price can be viewed as a function of several state variables—recent prices, momentum, volatility, and volume—corresponding to a point on a high-dimensional response surface. Over a sufficiently small neighborhood around the current market state, this surface can be locally approximated by a linear function. In this sense, even a complex nonlinear model behaves approximately linearly in the immediate vicinity of the observations on which it is trained.

This local approximation helps explain why short-horizon predictability may exist despite the absence of reliable long-term forecasting power. Small changes in inputs lead to proportionally small changes in the predicted price, allowing the model to exploit local structure without committing to a global trend. As the market state evolves and moves away from this neighborhood, however, the approximation deteriorates quickly, naturally limiting the persistence of predictability and helping to explain why even modest transaction costs can overwhelm the signal.

Formally, the next-day price can be represented as a multivariable function

where the inputs ​ represent features such as lagged prices, average trend, volatility.

Algorithmic Perspective: RMSE Minimization and Ensemble Averaging

From an algorithmic standpoint, this behavior arises not from explicit linearization, but from the way random forests are constructed.  Each decision tree is built through a greedy, recursive procedure that selects split points to locally minimize the root of the mean squared error (RMSE) of the next-day price prediction.  At each node, the algorithm chooses the variable and threshold that most reduces in-sample error, without considering the global structure of the tree or future splits.  This process produces a piecewise-constant approximation that is locally optimized for short-horizon accuracy.  The random forest then averages predictions across many such trees, each trained on a bootstrap sample and a random subset of predictors, which reduces variance and stabilizes forecasts.  As a result, the model captures local regularities in the data while remaining inherently sensitive to changes in market conditions, reinforcing the short-lived nature of the observed predictability.

Formally, at each node of a given tree, the algorithm selects a split (j, s) — variable x and threshold s — that minimizes the in-sample squared error within that node.  Let I denote the set of observations reaching the node.  The optimal split solves

where IL and IR are the left and right child nodes induced by the split.  Y bars are the mean next-day prices within each child.  This greedy optimization is repeated recursively until stopping criteria — such as minimum node size or maximum depth — are reached.

Because each tree is trained on a bootstrap sample of the data, approximately one-third of observations are excluded from the construction of any given tree.  These unused observations provide a natural out-of-sample testing set for that tree, forming the basis of the out-of-bag (OOB) error used to assess predictive performance.

Next came the testing of the OOB and tree pruning.

Without full statistical rigor of rules such as 1-SE, just visually it appears that 100 trees is enough to bring the error (Mean Square Error) down to almost its minimum. We can formally compare various error levels by the number of trees to make the pruning decision:

  Trees Train_RMSE Test_RMSE

1     5    1182.18   2397.00

2    20    1080.01   2244.43

3    50    1067.00   2222.47

4   100    1036.87   2207.22

5   200    1058.35   2183.04

One can see that the rate of MSE decrease drops, or slows down, between 100 and 200 trees. Based on this information, our heuristic cutoff is established at 100 trees.

PREDICTION: RMSE

 

The predicted distribution tells the following story:

  • Extreme ends move further away from the ideal line (red dotted line).
  • Vertical dotted lines between the predicted values (stock prices) and the red dotted line, if squared and summed, comprise the MSE.
  • Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) is 2188 (in Vietnamese dongs) which translates into less than 3% of the stock price level.  

So, we can proceed to plotting the predictions against the historical data.

The blue line represents historical stock prices (80% oldest), the red line is also historical stock prices, but newest (our model’s testing data) and green dots are the stock price predictions. First plot shows the entire data and second one zooms in on the testing data mostly:

Visually, the green dots (predictions) track the red line (actual stock prices) closely. There are some notable deviations though, but in general for the two-year period our basic random forest model performs reasonably well.

 

BASIC RANDOM FOREST REFINEMENT

Given the noticeable deviations of predictions from the actual stock prices, we introduce more predictors:

  1. Lag_1: one day prior share price. While this limits the predictive interval to only one day, this addition, as we see later, improves the predictive power.
  2. SMA_5 which is simple 5-day moving average =  

 

 

  1. EMA_12 which is 12-day exponential moving average, i.e. moving average where we assign higher weight to the most recent stock price

where a=2 / (N+1)

 

  1. We construct an average intraday price proxy for smoothing purposes as follows:  avg_daily=(open+low+high)/3. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The model essentially asks, “Given the prior day’s stock price and the short-term trend & momentum today, what price do we expect tomorrow?”

  • Lag-1 → inertia / memory
  • SMA & EMA → short-term trend
  • RSI → overbought / oversold pressure
  • MACD → momentum turning points

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Addition of these incremental variables brings the RMSE significantly down: from 2188 (below 3% of the stock price) to 809 which is below 1% of the stock price.

In plain English: this random forest regression predicts stock prices fairly closely to their actual levels at short horizons. 

 

RANDOM FOREST: TRUE PREDICTIONS

The logic of the random forest model has been clear: train the model on the 80% of historical data then make predictions for the 20% of the newest historical data, i.e., test the model on the unseen data. From this point, we went further – predicting Masan Group’s stock prices for a few days in a row.  Specifically

  • Original model’s last day of known stock price was Friday December 12, 2025. How does the model perform on the following Monday when the markets open?  I.e., what stock price does it predict for Monday December 15, 2025?
  • For Tuesday December 16, 2025, stock prediction, I add the prices from Monday and re-run the model to predict December 16 price. I repeated this process for two weeks through December 26 especially noting the period of “Santa rally” as during this period the deviations may be interesting.

Rather than holding the model fixed, we re-train the random forest each day as new observations become available. This expanding-window approach allows the model to adapt to evolving market conditions and prevents mechanical error accumulation.  This differs from recursive multi-step forecasting with a fixed model, where forecast errors compound over time.

Here are the results:

While each daily forecast is strictly out-of-sample, the resulting multi-day prediction path should be interpreted as a conditional scenario generated by a sequence of re-trained models rather than as a set of independent forecasts from a fixed model.  Predictions generated this way paint an interesting picture:

  • Typical prediction error or edge: ~0.5%–1.5%
  • Often much smaller day-to-day moves
  • Pragmatically, any usable signal is small relative to the price level, consistent with liquid asset classes
  • This may be important if the round-trip costs run up to 0.10% (5 bps for entry and exit trades respectively)

Here is the plot of these predictions against the actual stock price movements from December 12, 2025:

We can interpret a few representative trading days and our predictions:

RANDOM FOREST ON MASAN GROUP STOCK PRICE: CONCLUSION

At first glance, the random forest model appears to perform well: predicted prices track actual prices closely, and RMSE falls below 1% once lagged price and moving-average features are introduced. However, a closer examination reveals that much of this apparent predictive power is mechanical rather than informational.

Equity prices are highly autocorrelated at short horizons, particularly for relatively low-volatility stocks such as Masan Group.  

  • As a result, introducing the prior day’s price (Lag_1) almost mechanically improves prediction accuracy, effectively reducing the problem to “tomorrow equals today plus noise.”
  • In this sense, the model’s success is not evidence of alpha generation, but rather a reflection of short-term price persistence.

Although each daily forecast is strictly out-of-sample, the resulting multi-day path should still be interpreted cautiously: economically rather than statistically.  Because predictions are generated by a sequence of re-trained models rather than a single fixed model, the path represents a conditional evolution under expanding information rather than a fully independent set of forecasts.

INTO THE FUTURE: ITERATION 2: RETURN-BASED RANDOM FOREST (vs. Baselines)

These observations do not weaken the analysis; instead, they clarify the path toward a more rigorous modeling framework.  A more economically meaningful approach is to model price changes rather than price levels, for example by predicting log returns.

This transformation removes non-stationarity, forces the model to learn directional information, and reduces reliance on trivial persistence effects.

In the subsequent iteration, we will also introduce the trading costs, e.g., at 5bps.  This estimate highlights that even modest transaction costs can exceed the typical day-to-day predictive edge, rendering statistically accurate forecasts economically unprofitable.

In addition, any refined model must be evaluated against simple baseline alternatives such as a random walk (e.g., “tomorrow = today”), ARIMA, or moving-average extrapolation.  

  • Only if the random forest consistently outperforms these “lazy” benchmarks can it be said to add genuine predictive value.
  • Beating the baseline is, in practice, the definition of alpha.

In this sense, the current model serves an important diagnostic role: it demonstrates both the power and the limitations of machine learning applied naively to equity prices, and it motivates a more disciplined next iteration grounded in financial time-series principles.

entry.title: Migration of XSA between OS with different CPU architecture
entry.content:
You are planning to migrate your SAP system with integrated XSA from one OS to another and both have different architecture.

Note: I am writing this blog in reference to HTC migration (Where the source was running on Linux PowerPC ppc641e 64 bit (Little Endian) and target was running on Linux x86-64)

Pre-req 

On target you have installed XSA with version same or higher as comparison to source.

In the start you have to follow normal process (Follow SAP Note 3445668)

Disable XSA on target (XSA disable)

Run the backup XSA command on source (XSA backup-fss)

Once above backup completed start the replication and perform take over.

After takeover restore the XSA on target and then enable XSA. ( XSA select-xsa-runtime-db <Tenant DB> )

Once the XSA enabled you will see that even though all the XSA services are running successfully but instances of the apps in SAP space are not running. ( Even though if you try restaging the apps it will not work)

Now check the runtimes here you will find that the some of the runtimes are CPU architecture dependent and will be based on the source. But as on the target we have different architecture the runtimes from the source will not work and therefor the apps are not starting.

Don't worry we have solution for this 

First take a note of all the runtimes those are arcitecture dependent. Below is the example you will get it when you run "xs runtimes" (Better to have scrrenshots of XS runtimes before moving ahead as we will need this later for reference)

node14.21 14.21.3.0    48(ID)      true     true     Node.js 14.21.3 for Linux x86-64 (architecture dependent)    10 (Bound apps)

 

Take note of ID, Bound apps with version of the node as you have to install the same version later or the bounded apps will not start.

Now with the help of runtime ID's one by one delete all the source dependent runtimes.

xs delete-runtime -f -i <ID> (make sure you are only deleting the platform dependent runtimes don't delete anything else)

 

Once all the runtimes are deleted use hdblcm and the same XSA package (You used to install the XSA) and update the XSA related components.

After the component update is finished again check the "xs runtimes" and compare it with the older runtimes screenshots check if all the runtimes with bounded apps came or not.

In our case customer was having older versions of node on source and have bounded apps with it.

After update components we only got node version 16 and 18. 

But customer have some apps bounded to node version 14, 12 and 10. 

So to install the older runtimes we downloaded previous XSA SAR files from SAP for me.

And then extracted the older node version from there. 

This is not a recommeded approch but as we were in middle of the migration we don't have any option left. And also customer confirmed that they will update the XSA components to latest version after the migration.

We followed below approch to install the older node version.

  1. download XSA 1.0155 installation SAR (EXTAPPSER00P_155-70001316.SAR)
  2. extract it to some temporary directory ("sapcar -xvf EXTAPPSER00P_155-70001316.SAR)
  3. extract the contained file "packages/INITIAL_CONTENT.TGZ ("tar xvfz INITIAL_CONTENT.TGZ")
  4. in the contained installdata/runtimes directory, you will find node-12.x, which you can install with
    xs create-runtime -p installdata/runtimes/node-12.x (first perform "xs-admin-login" and then create the runtime) 

    xs create-runtime -p $XSPATH/node_14 (This is how we installed node 14)

     

  5.  

    Once you have created all the required runtimes perform the restage of the apps using below command.

    xs runtimes (It will show that you have got the runtimes dependent on the target architecture)

    XSA restage-at-startup

    XSA restart 

    Once the restart is completed you will see that the standard apps in SPACE SAP are running fine.

    If any apps are still not running than try the restage for that individual app and then restart the app.

    xs restage <APP name>

    xs restart <APP name>

    Once this is done execute all the XSA post migration related commands.

entry.title: Canada T4A-NR 2025 Regulatory Changes: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance(DRC)
entry.content:
Towards the end of 2025, the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) rolled out updates to the T4A-NR slip, summary forms, and the T619 XML schema. These changes, which will affect filings due on or before the last day of February 2026, have been seamlessly integrated into SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solutions, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition /On-Premise. Here’s a detailed look at what these updates entail and how SAP is ensuring compliance.

Key Regulatory Changes

  1. Updated CRA Forms: The CRA has released new 2025 versions of the T4A-NR slip and the T4A-NR Summary (T4A-NR-SUM) for the 2025 tax year. While the content changes are minimal, using the correct form version is essential to avoid filing issues.
  2. T619 XML Schema Updates:
    • Mandatory Language Code: To ensure consistent language identification for CRA communications, the T619 electronic transmittal now requires a language code to specify English or French, denoted by “E” or “F” for every submission. Previously optional, this field is now mandatory for 2025 filings.
    • No Empty Fields in XML: A new validation rule mandates that any optional XML element with no data must be omitted entirely. This means if a data field doesn’t apply or is blank, the system should not generate that XML tag at all, as including empty tags can lead to file rejection by the CRA. 

SAP's Support of Regulatory Changes

As part ofSAP’s end-to-end compliance vision, the SAP Globalization Product Management team has proactively delivered the necessary updates to accommodate these CRA changes, to ensure that customers can generate compliant T4A-NR slips, summaries, and XML files across SAP Cloud ERP solutions:

  • SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: The T4A-NR form and summary Adobe print forms have been updated in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) and SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud to match the CRA’s 2025 PDF layout. Electronic filing content for T4A-NR has been enhanced to output XML according to the new schema, delivered via the regular quarterly release.
  •  SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition/On-Premise: SAP Note 3691523 – “Canada T4A-NR Withholding Tax Reporting: Legal Changes 2025” was released, along with a support package containing the updated forms and electronic report definitions. Applying this note or support pack will ensure the system produces the correct 2025 forms and XML.

Next Steps 

  • Review and Implement SAP Update: Ensure your SAP S/4HANA system has the 2025 year-end legal change for T4A-NR applied. For SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, apply SAP Note 3691523. For SAP S/4HANA Cloud, confirm you’re on the latest release that includes the T4A-NR changes. Implement these updates before year-end processing.
  • Test Your Reporting: Generate a sample T4A-NR slip, summary, and XML file in a test environment. Verify that the slip and summary display “2025” and the latest form text. Ensure the language element is present and correctly set, and confirm that there are no empty tags in the file.
  • Consult CRA Resources: Refer to the CRA’s official XML specifications page for the updated schema download and guidance for 2025/2026 filings. The CRA’s T4A-NR guide (RC4445) for 2025, updated December 2025, is also a helpful reference. Links to the schema files and CRA documentation are available on the CRA website.

Call to Action

SAP customers and partners can avoid last-minute scrambles and ensure a smooth tax filing season by taking the following actions:

  • Review our published "What's New" SAP Help Portal documentation, apply, and test the delivered SAP changes promptly.
  • Engage your IT or SAP support team to confirm that your system is outputting the new form and schema correctly. Leverage the Regulatory Change Manager for agility in adapting to new legal requirements.
  • Visit the CRA’s XML specification page for the official schema and test your files against it. With proper preparation, you’ll be ready to file your 2025 T4A‑NR returns without issues.
  • Connect with us via the SAP support channels or Canada Localization Workzone if questions arise during this update process.

entry.title: Comparison of Rate Routing and Routing in SAP
entry.content:
Overview

In SAP Production Planning (PP), Routing and Rate Routing are both task lists that define manufacturing operations. While they share similarities, they cater to different manufacturing scenarios and differ in time calculation, setup requirements, and application contexts.

Comparison Table


 
 
Parameter
Rate RoutingRouting
Definition
Defines production quantity and fixed duration to establish production rates.Defines a sequence of operations with detailed times for each step.
Primary Use Case
Repetitive manufacturing and flow production.Discrete manufacturing and production orders.
Time Definition
Based on production rate (quantity per time period).Based on setup, processing, and teardown times per operation.
Setup Time
Typically not defined.Defined for each operation.
Manufacturing Type
Repetitive/Flow manufacturing.Discrete manufacturing.
Sequence Types
Standard and parallel sequences only.Standard, parallel, and alternative sequences.
Transaction Codes
CA21 (Create), CA22 (Change), CA23 (Display).CA01 (Create), CA02 (Change), CA03 (Display).
Costing Approach
Period-based costing.Order-based costing.

Key Differences

  • Time Calculation:
    • Rate Routing → Defines production rates (quantity per time).
    • Routing → Defines operation times (time per quantity).
  • Sequence Flexibility:
    • Rate Routing → No alternative sequences (only standard and parallel).
    • Routing → Supports alternative sequences.
  • Manufacturing Philosophy:
    • Rate Routing → Designed for lean, continuous production.
    • Routing → Suited for varied discrete manufacturing scenarios.

When to Use Each

Rate Routing

  • For repetitive manufacturing with continuous production flows.
  • When products are made in large volumes with consistent rates.
  • In flow manufacturing environments with minimal setup changes.
  • When using Product Cost Collectors (PCC) for period-based costing.
  • For assembly backflush scenarios (e.g., transaction MFBF).

Routing

  • For discrete manufacturing with varied lot sizes.
  • When alternative sequences or flexible operations are required.
  • When detailed setup, processing, and teardown times are needed.
  • For order-based production with specific requirements.

Common Misconceptions

  • Interchangeability: While both can be used in repetitive manufacturing, Rate Routing is recommended for REM due to its design for continuous production and backflushing compatibility.
  • Functionality: Rate Routing offers similar functions as Routing but is optimized for rate-based production.
  • Alternative Sequences: The absence of alternative sequences in Rate Routing is intentional, aligning with standardized repetitive processes.

Recommendation

  • Choose Rate Routing for repetitive manufacturing with standardized processes, continuous flows, and period-based costing.
  • Choose Routing for discrete manufacturing requiring operational flexibility, alternative sequences, and detailed time definitions.

Your choice should align with your manufacturing strategy and costing approach.

Today I’d like to share a small but useful development I recently created — a reusable function module that displays a popup to collect a single value entered by the user.

The idea was to create a lightweight and generic solution to obtain user input through a popup, similar to some standard dialogs but fully customizable and easy to reuse across different programs and languages.

The function module was implemented in the standard function group SPO3, and I created a custom screen 101 specifically for this purpose. The screen contains a single input field and standard OK/Cancel buttons, providing a very simple user interaction.  Also, to allow the user to select a date using the standard SAP Calendar, I added the search help BU_DATE_CHAR to the input field.
