Hi SAP Community! 👋

Today I’d like to share a custom ABAP Development that I created to simplify and automate a very common operational need: the mass creation of Purchase Requisitions (PRs).

In many organizations, users frequently need to create large volumes of PRs based on spreadsheets, external data, or recurring patterns. Doing this manually through ME51N can be time-consuming, error-prone, and inefficient.

To address this, I developed a standalone program that reads structured input data and automatically creates PRs in bulk, providing clear logs and validation checks.

Report ZMM_LOG_PG03:

REPORT zmm_log_pg03.

INCLUDE:
  zmm_log_pg03_top,
  zmm_log_pg03_lcl,
  zmm_log_pg03_scr,
  zmm_log_pg03_f01.

Include ZMM_LOG_PG03_TOP:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Include          ZMM_LOG_PG01_TOP
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*


TYPES:
  BEGIN OF gtyp_post.
    INCLUDE TYPE zmm_log_st03.
TYPES:
    bsart TYPE bbsrt,
    knttp TYPE knttp,
    ernam TYPE ernam,
    kostl TYPE kostl,
    ekorg TYPE ekorg,
    ekgrp TYPE ekgrp,
  END OF gtyp_post,
  BEGIN OF gtyp_imp_exp,
    matnr	TYPE matnr,
    menge	TYPE char16,
    werks	TYPE werks_d,
    lgort	TYPE lgort_d,
    lfdat	TYPE char10,
    flief	TYPE flief,
  END OF gtyp_imp_exp,
  BEGIN OF gtyp_imp_exp_ini,
    matnr	TYPE string,
    menge	TYPE string,
    werks	TYPE string,
    lgort	TYPE string,
    lfdat	TYPE string,
    flief	TYPE string,
  END OF gtyp_imp_exp_ini,
  BEGIN OF gtyp_num_errors,
    index TYPE sytabix,
    value TYPE char20,
  END OF gtyp_num_errors,
  BEGIN OF gtyp_date_errors,
    index TYPE sytabix,
    value TYPE char20,
  END OF gtyp_date_errors.


CONSTANTS:
  gc_matkl TYPE rvari_vnam VALUE 'ZMMPURREQ_MATGROUP'.

CLASS: lcl_eventhandler DEFINITION DEFERRED.

DATA:
  BEGIN: OF gt_excl OCCURS 0,
    code TYPE syst_ucomm,
  END OF gt_excl.

DATA:
  gt_out             TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zmm_log_st03,
  gt_out_ini         TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF zmm_log_st03,
  gs_out             TYPE zmm_log_st03,
  gt_post            TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gtyp_post,
  gs_post            TYPE gtyp_post,
  gt_import          TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gtyp_imp_exp,
  gt_num_errors      TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gtyp_num_errors WITH KEY index,
  gs_num_errors      TYPE gtyp_num_errors,
  gt_date_errors     TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF gtyp_date_errors WITH KEY index,
  gs_date_errors     TYPE gtyp_date_errors,
  gt_protocol_import TYPE lvc_t_msg1,
  gt_rows            TYPE lvc_t_row,
  gs_rows            TYPE lvc_s_row,
  gr_matkl           TYPE RANGE OF matkl,
  gs_matkl           LIKE LINE OF gr_matkl,
  go_container       TYPE REF TO cl_gui_custom_container,
  go_alv             TYPE REF TO cl_gui_alv_grid,
  go_events          TYPE REF TO lcl_eventhandler,
  gv_answer          TYPE char1,
  gv_import          TYPE xfeld,
  gv_progress        TYPE xfeld,
  gv_errors          TYPE xfeld,
  gv_rows            TYPE int4,
  gv_selall          TYPE xfeld.

Include ZMM_LOG_PG03_LCL:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Include          ZMM_LOG_PG01_LCL
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*

CLASS lcl_eventhandler DEFINITION.

  PUBLIC SECTION.

    CLASS-METHODS:

      handle_data_changed FOR EVENT data_changed OF cl_gui_alv_grid
        IMPORTING
          er_data_changed.


ENDCLASS.                    "lcl_eventhandler DEFINITION

*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*       CLASS lcl_eventhandler IMPLEMENTATION
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
CLASS lcl_eventhandler IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD handle_data_changed.

    CONSTANTS:
      lv_tabname TYPE tabname VALUE 'ZMM_LOG_ST03'.

    FIELD-SYMBOLS:
      <lfs_value>         TYPE any,
      <lfs_value_o>       TYPE any,
      <lv_value_ref>      TYPE any,
      <lfs_ls_add_fields> TYPE dcfielddat.

    DATA:
      lo_data_changed    TYPE REF TO cl_alv_changed_data_protocol,
      lo_struct          TYPE REF TO cl_abap_structdescr,
      lr_data            TYPE REF TO data,
      lt_comp            TYPE abap_component_tab,
      ls_comp            TYPE abap_componentdescr,
      ls_protocol_import TYPE lvc_s_msg1,
      lt_failure         TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ddfkeyrc,
      ls_failure         TYPE ddfkeyrc,
      lt_add_fields      TYPE dcfielddats,
      ls_good_cell       TYPE lvc_s_modi,
      ls_mod_cell        TYPE lvc_s_modi,
      ls_mod_cell2       TYPE lvc_s_modi,
      ls_mod_cell_add    TYPE lvc_s_modi,
      lv_value           TYPE lvc_value,
      lv_value_o         TYPE lvc_value,
      ls_out             TYPE zmm_log_st03,
      lv_row_id          TYPE int4,
      lv_fieldn	         TYPE lvc_fname,
      lv_fieldname       TYPE fnam_____4,
      ls_syst            TYPE syst,
      lv_msgno           TYPE symsgno,
      lv_msgv1           TYPE char120,
      lv_msgv2           TYPE char120,
      lv_msgv3           TYPE char120,
      lv_proc_f          TYPE f,
      lv_proc            TYPE sy-tabix,
      lv_werks           TYPE werks_d,
      lv_lgort           TYPE lgort_d,
      lv_matnr           TYPE matnr,
      lv_mmsta           TYPE mmsta,
      lv_lifnr           TYPE lifnr,
      lv_datbi           TYPE datbi,
      lv_lines           TYPE i,
      lv_date_format(15) TYPE c.


    IF er_data_changed IS NOT BOUND.
      EXIT.
    ENDIF.

    IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL.

      FREE: er_data_changed->mt_mod_cells.

      lo_struct ?= cl_abap_typedescr=>describe_by_data( ls_out ).
      lt_comp = lo_struct->get_components( ).

      LOOP AT gt_out INTO ls_out.
        lv_row_id = sy-tabix.
        LOOP AT lt_comp INTO ls_comp.
          lv_fieldn = ls_comp-name.
          ASSIGN COMPONENT lv_fieldn OF STRUCTURE ls_out TO <lfs_value_o>.
          IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL AND <lfs_value_o> IS ASSIGNED.
            er_data_changed->modify_cell(
              i_row_id    = lv_row_id
              i_tabix     = lv_row_id
              i_fieldname = lv_fieldn
              i_value     = <lfs_value_o>
            ).
            UNASSIGN <lfs_value_o>.
          ENDIF.
        ENDLOOP.
      ENDLOOP.

      gt_protocol_import = er_data_changed->mt_protocol.

    ELSE.

      LOOP AT er_data_changed->mt_mod_cells INTO ls_mod_cell.
        DELETE gt_protocol_import WHERE row_id = ls_mod_cell-row_id AND fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname.
      ENDLOOP.
      FREE: er_data_changed->mt_protocol.
      CALL METHOD er_data_changed->refresh_protocol.
      LOOP AT gt_protocol_import INTO ls_protocol_import.
        CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = ls_protocol_import-msgid
            i_msgty     = ls_protocol_import-msgty
            i_msgno     = ls_protocol_import-msgno
            i_msgv1     = ls_protocol_import-msgv1
            i_msgv2     = ls_protocol_import-msgv2
            i_msgv3     = ls_protocol_import-msgv3
            i_msgv4     = ls_protocol_import-msgv4
            i_fieldname = ls_protocol_import-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_protocol_import-row_id.
      ENDLOOP.


    ENDIF.


    DESCRIBE TABLE er_data_changed->mt_mod_cells LINES lv_lines.

    LOOP AT er_data_changed->mt_mod_cells INTO ls_mod_cell.

      READ TABLE gt_out INTO ls_out INDEX  ls_mod_cell-row_id.

      lv_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname.
      IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL.
        ASSIGN COMPONENT lv_fieldname OF STRUCTURE ls_out TO <lfs_value_o>.
        lv_value_o = <lfs_value_o>.

* EXT_DMSF (23/09/2025) - START

        lv_msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        SHIFT lv_msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.

        IF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'MATNR'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '197'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ELSEIF lv_fieldname = 'MENGE'.
          SHIFT lv_value_o LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
          IF lv_value_o = '' OR lv_value_o = '0.000'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '198'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
          ENDIF.
        ELSEIF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'WERKS'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '199'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ELSEIF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'LGORT'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '200'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ELSEIF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'LFDAT'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '201'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ELSEIF lv_value_o = '' AND lv_fieldname = 'FLIEF'.
          CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = '202'
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
            i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
        ENDIF.

* END

      ELSE.
        lv_value_o = ls_mod_cell-value.
      ENDIF.

      FREE: gs_post.
      READ TABLE gt_post INTO gs_post INDEX ls_mod_cell-row_id.


      CASE ls_mod_cell-fieldname.
        WHEN 'MATNR' OR 'WERKS' OR 'LGORT'.
          FREE: lt_failure, lt_add_fields.
          IF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'MATNR'.
            CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_MATN1_INPUT'
              EXPORTING
                input         = lv_value_o
              IMPORTING
                output        = lv_value_o.
          ENDIF.
          CALL FUNCTION 'DDUT_INPUT_CHECK'
            EXPORTING
              tabname           = lv_tabname
              fieldname         = lv_fieldname
              value             = lv_value_o
            TABLES
              failure_tab       = lt_failure
            CHANGING
              additional_fields = lt_add_fields
            EXCEPTIONS
              no_ddic_field     = 1
              illegal_move      = 2
              OTHERS            = 3.
          IF lt_add_fields IS NOT INITIAL.
            LOOP AT lt_add_fields ASSIGNING <lfs_ls_add_fields>.
              ASSIGN COMPONENT <lfs_ls_add_fields>-fieldname OF STRUCTURE ls_out TO <lfs_value>.
              IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL AND <lfs_value> IS ASSIGNED.
                ASSIGN <lfs_ls_add_fields>-value->* TO <lv_value_ref>.
                IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL AND <lv_value_ref> IS ASSIGNED.
                  ASSIGN <lfs_ls_add_fields>-value->* TO <lv_value_ref>.
                  <lv_value_ref> =  <lfs_value>.
                  <lfs_ls_add_fields>-found =  abap_true.
                  UNASSIGN <lv_value_ref>.
                ENDIF.
                UNASSIGN <lfs_value>.
              ENDIF.
            ENDLOOP.
            REFRESH: lt_failure.
            CALL FUNCTION 'DDUT_INPUT_CHECK'
              EXPORTING
                tabname           = lv_tabname
                fieldname         = lv_fieldname
                value             = lv_value_o
              TABLES
                failure_tab       = lt_failure
              CHANGING
                additional_fields = lt_add_fields
              EXCEPTIONS
                no_ddic_field     = 1
                illegal_move      = 2
                OTHERS            = 3.
          ENDIF.
          IF lt_failure IS NOT INITIAL.
            LOOP AT lt_failure INTO ls_failure.
              ls_failure-arbgb = 'ZMM'.
              lv_msgno = ls_failure-msgnr.
              IF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'WERKS'.
                lv_msgno = 184.
                ls_failure-msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                SHIFT ls_failure-msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
              ELSEIF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'LGORT'.
                lv_msgno = 185.
                ls_failure-msgv1 = ls_out-lgort.
                ls_failure-msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                SHIFT ls_failure-msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                ls_failure-msgv3 = ls_out-werks.
              ELSEIF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'MATNR'.
                lv_msgno = 181.
                ls_failure-msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                SHIFT ls_failure-msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                ls_failure-msgv3 = lv_werks.
                ls_failure-msgv4 = ls_out-lgort.
              ENDIF.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = ls_failure-arbgb
                  i_msgty     = ls_failure-msgty
                  i_msgno     = lv_msgno
                  i_msgv1     = ls_failure-msgv1
                  i_msgv2     = ls_failure-msgv2
                  i_msgv3     = ls_failure-msgv3
                  i_msgv4     = ls_failure-msgv4
                  i_fieldname = ls_failure-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDLOOP.
          ELSE.
            IF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'MATNR'.

              SELECT SINGLE matnr
                  FROM mara
                 WHERE matnr = @LV_value_o
                  INTO @LV_matnr.
              IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
                lv_msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                SHIFT lv_msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                  EXPORTING
                    i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                    i_msgty     = 'E'
                    i_msgno     = 179
                    i_msgv1     = lv_value_o
                    i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
                    i_msgv3     = lv_werks
                    i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                    i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
              ENDIF.

              SELECT SINGLE matnr
                  FROM mara
                 WHERE matnr = @LV_value_o
                   AND matkl IN @GR_matkl
                  INTO @LV_matnr.
              IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
                lv_msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                READ TABLE gr_matkl INTO gs_matkl INDEX 1.
                IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
                  lv_msgv3 = gs_matkl-low.
                ENDIF.
                SHIFT lv_msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                  EXPORTING
                    i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                    i_msgty     = 'E'
                    i_msgno     = 180
                    i_msgv1     = lv_value_o
                    i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
                    i_msgv3     = lv_msgv3
                    i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                    i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
              ENDIF.

              lv_werks = ls_out-werks.
              IF lv_value_o IS NOT INITIAL AND lv_werks IS NOT INITIAL.
                SELECT SINGLE mmsta
                  FROM marc
                 WHERE matnr = @LV_value_o
                   AND werks = @LV_werks
                   AND mmsta IS INITIAL
                  INTO @LV_mmsta.
                IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
                  lv_msgv2 = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                  SHIFT lv_msgv2 LEFT DELETING LEADING space.
                  CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                    EXPORTING
                      i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                      i_msgty     = 'E'
                      i_msgno     = 182
                      i_msgv1     = lv_value_o
                      i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
                      i_msgv3     = lv_werks
                      i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                      i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
                ENDIF.
              ENDIF.
            ENDIF.

          ENDIF.


          IF ls_mod_cell-fieldname = 'MATNR'.
            FREE: lv_value.
            SELECT SINGLE maktx
              INTO lv_value
              FROM makt
             WHERE matnr = lv_value_o
               AND spras = sy-langu.
            er_data_changed->modify_cell(
              i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id
              i_fieldname = 'MAKTX'
              i_value     = lv_value
            ).


            IF gs_post-bsart IS INITIAL.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                  i_msgty     = 'E'
                  i_msgno     = 188
                  i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDIF.

            IF gs_post-knttp IS INITIAL.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                  i_msgty     = 'E'
                  i_msgno     = 189
                  i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDIF.

            IF gs_post-ekorg IS INITIAL OR gs_post-ekgrp IS INITIAL.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                  i_msgty     = 'E'
                  i_msgno     = 191
                  i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDIF.


*                bsart TYPE bbsrt,
*    knttp TYPE knttp,
*    ernam TYPE ernam,
*    kostl TYPE kostl,
*    ekorg TYPE ekorg,
*    ekgrp TYPE ekgrp,
          ENDIF.


        WHEN 'LFDAT'.
          READ TABLE gt_date_errors WITH KEY index = ls_mod_cell-row_id
                                    TRANSPORTING NO FIELDS.
          IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
*            IF ls_mod_cell-value <> sy-datum.
            IF lv_value_o <> sy-datum. " EXT_DMSF (26/09/2025)
              WRITE ls_mod_cell-row_id TO lv_msgv1 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
              CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
                EXPORTING
                  i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                  i_msgty     = 'W'
                  i_msgno     = 192
                  i_msgv1     = lv_msgv1
                  i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                  i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
            ENDIF.
          ENDIF.

        WHEN 'FLIEF'.
          UNPACK lv_value_o TO lv_lifnr.
          SELECT SINGLE lifnr
            INTO lv_lifnr
            FROM lfm1
           WHERE lifnr = lv_lifnr
             AND ekorg = gs_post-ekorg.
          IF sy-subrc IS NOT INITIAL.
            lv_msgv2 = gs_post-ekorg.
            CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
              EXPORTING
                i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
                i_msgty     = 'E'
                i_msgno     = 187
                i_msgv1     = lv_value_o
                i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
                i_fieldname = ls_mod_cell-fieldname
                i_row_id    = ls_mod_cell-row_id.
          ENDIF.

      ENDCASE.

    ENDLOOP.

    IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL AND gt_num_errors IS NOT INITIAL.
      LOOP AT gt_num_errors INTO gs_num_errors.
        WRITE gs_num_errors-value TO lv_msgv1 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
        WRITE gs_num_errors-index TO lv_msgv2 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
        CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = 183
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv1
            i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = 'MENGE'
            i_row_id    = gs_num_errors-index.
*        er_data_changed->modify_cell(
*          i_row_id    = gs_num_errors-index
*          i_fieldname = 'MENGE'
*          i_value     = gs_num_errors-value
*        ).
      ENDLOOP.
      FREE: gt_num_errors.
    ENDIF.

    IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL AND gt_date_errors IS NOT INITIAL.
      LOOP AT gt_date_errors INTO gs_date_errors.
        WRITE gs_date_errors-value TO lv_msgv1 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
        WRITE gs_date_errors-index TO lv_msgv2 LEFT-JUSTIFIED.
        CALL METHOD er_data_changed->add_protocol_entry
          EXPORTING
            i_msgid     = 'ZMM'
            i_msgty     = 'E'
            i_msgno     = 186
            i_msgv1     = lv_msgv1
            i_msgv2     = lv_msgv2
            i_fieldname = 'LFDAT'
            i_row_id    = gs_date_errors-index.
        er_data_changed->modify_cell(
          i_row_id    = gs_date_errors-index
          i_fieldname = 'LFDAT'
          i_value     = gs_date_errors-value
        ).
      ENDLOOP.
      FREE: gt_date_errors.
    ENDIF.


    CALL METHOD er_data_changed->display_protocol.

    IF gv_import IS NOT INITIAL.
      FREE: gv_import.
      gt_protocol_import = er_data_changed->mt_protocol.
      CALL METHOD go_alv->refresh_table_display.
    ENDIF.
    FREE: gv_progress.

    IF er_data_changed->mt_protocol IS INITIAL.
      FREE: gv_errors.
    ELSE.
      READ TABLE er_data_changed->mt_protocol WITH KEY msgty = 'E'
                                              TRANSPORTING NO FIELDS.
      IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
        gv_errors = abap_true.
      ELSE.
        FREE: gv_errors.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.

  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.                    "lcl_eventhandler IMPLEMENTATION

*&      Form  F_ALV_DISPLAY
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------**
FORM f_alv_display .

  DATA:
    lo_tabledescr TYPE REF TO cl_abap_structdescr,
    lo_data       TYPE REF TO data,
    lt_dfies      TYPE ddfields,
    ls_dfies      TYPE dfies,
    ls_layout     TYPE lvc_s_layo,
    lt_exclude    TYPE ui_functions,
    ls_exclude    TYPE ui_func,
    lt_fieldcat   TYPE lvc_t_fcat,
    ls_fieldcat   TYPE lvc_s_fcat,
    lt_dropdown   TYPE lvc_t_drop,
    ls_dropdown   TYPE lvc_s_drop,
    ls_color      TYPE lvc_s_colo.

    ls_consumos    TYPE zmm_consumos,
    lt_matkl_prdha TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ltyp_matkl_prdha WITH NON-UNIQUE KEY matnr,
    ls_matkl_prdha TYPE ltyp_matkl_prdha,
    lv_prdha       TYPE prodh_d,
    lv_filename    TYPE string,
    lv_rows        TYPE int4,
    lv_tabix       TYPE sytabix,
    lv_rc          TYPE i.

  FREE: gt_out.
  CALL METHOD go_alv->refresh_table_display.

  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>file_open_dialog
    EXPORTING
      window_title            = 'Importar CSV'
      default_extension       = 'CSV'
      default_filename        = '*.CSV'
      file_filter             = '*.CSV'
      multiselection          = abap_false
    CHANGING
      file_table              = lt_filetable
      rc                      = lv_rc
    EXCEPTIONS
      file_open_dialog_failed = 1
      cntl_error              = 2
      error_no_gui            = 3
      not_supported_by_gui    = 4
      OTHERS                  = 5.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    FREE: lt_filetable.
  ENDIF.



  IF lt_filetable IS NOT INITIAL.
    READ TABLE lt_filetable INTO ls_filetable INDEX 1.
    lv_filename = ls_filetable.
    CALL FUNCTION 'GUI_UPLOAD'
      EXPORTING
        filename                = lv_filename
        filetype                = 'ASC'
        has_field_separator     = abap_true
        read_by_line            = 'X'
      TABLES
        data_tab                = lt_csv
      EXCEPTIONS
        file_open_error         = 1
        file_read_error         = 2
        no_batch                = 3
        gui_refuse_filetransfer = 4
        invalid_type            = 5
        no_authority            = 6
        unknown_error           = 7
        bad_data_format         = 8
        header_not_allowed      = 9
        separator_not_allowed   = 10
        header_too_long         = 11
        unknown_dp_error        = 12
        access_denied           = 13
        dp_out_of_memory        = 14
        disk_full               = 15
        dp_timeout              = 16
        OTHERS                  = 17.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      EXIT.
    ENDIF.


    FREE: lt_import.
    LOOP AT lt_csv INTO ls_csv.
      FREE: ls_import, ls_import_ini.
      IF sy-tabix = 1.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.
      lv_tabix = sy-tabix - 1.
      SPLIT ls_csv AT ';' INTO ls_import_ini-matnr ls_import_ini-menge ls_import_ini-werks
                               ls_import_ini-lgort ls_import_ini-lfdat ls_import_ini-flief.

      IF strlen( ls_import_ini-matnr ) > 18.
        ls_import-matnr = ls_import_ini-matnr(18).
      ELSE.
        ls_import-matnr = ls_import_ini-matnr.
      ENDIF.
      IF strlen( ls_import_ini-menge ) > 16.
        ls_import-menge = ls_import_ini-menge(16).
      ELSE.
        ls_import-menge = ls_import_ini-menge.
      ENDIF.
      IF strlen( ls_import_ini-werks ) > 4.
        ls_import-werks = ls_import_ini-werks(4).
      ELSE.
        ls_import-werks = ls_import_ini-werks.
      ENDIF.
      IF strlen( ls_import_ini-lgort ) > 4.
        ls_import-lgort = ls_import_ini-lgort(4).
      ELSE.
        ls_import-lgort = ls_import_ini-lgort.
      ENDIF.
      IF strlen( ls_import_ini-lfdat ) > 10.
        ls_import_ini-lfdat = ls_import_ini-lfdat(10).
      ENDIF.
      IF strlen( ls_import_ini-flief ) > 10.
        ls_import-flief = ls_import_ini-flief(10).
      ELSE.
        ls_import-flief = ls_import_ini-flief.
      ENDIF.
      TRANSLATE ls_import-menge  USING ',.'.
      IF zcl_mm_generic=>check_numeric( ls_import-menge ) IS NOT INITIAL.
        FREE: gs_num_errors.
        gs_num_errors-index = lv_tabix.
        gs_num_errors-value = ls_import_ini-menge.
        APPEND gs_num_errors TO gt_num_errors.
        FREE: ls_import-menge.
      ENDIF.
      IF ls_import_ini-lfdat IS INITIAL.
        FREE: gs_date_errors, ls_import-lfdat.
        gs_date_errors-index = lv_tabix.
        gs_date_errors-value = ls_import_ini-lfdat.
        APPEND gs_date_errors TO gt_date_errors.
      ELSEIF zcl_mm_generic=>check_date( ls_import_ini-lfdat ) IS INITIAL.
        CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERT_DATE_TO_INTERNAL'
          EXPORTING
            date_external            = ls_import_ini-lfdat
*           ACCEPT_INITIAL_DATE      =
          IMPORTING
            date_internal            = ls_import-lfdat
          EXCEPTIONS
            date_external_is_invalid = 1
            OTHERS                   = 2.
        IF sy-subrc <> 0.
          FREE: ls_import-lfdat.
          FREE: gs_date_errors, ls_import-lfdat.
          gs_date_errors-index = lv_tabix.
          gs_date_errors-value = ls_import_ini-lfdat.
          APPEND gs_date_errors TO gt_date_errors.
        ENDIF.
      ELSE.
        FREE: ls_import-lfdat.
        FREE: gs_date_errors, ls_import-lfdat.
        gs_date_errors-index = lv_tabix.
        gs_date_errors-value = ls_import_ini-lfdat.
        APPEND gs_date_errors TO gt_date_errors.
      ENDIF.
      APPEND ls_import TO lt_import.
    ENDLOOP.


    FREE: gt_out.
    CALL METHOD go_alv->refresh_table_display.

    gt_out = CORRESPONDING #( lt_import ).
    gt_out_ini = gt_out.

    CALL FUNCTION 'VIEW_GET_DATA'
      EXPORTING
        view_name              = 'V_T001K_ASSIGN'
      TABLES
        data                   = lt_assign
      EXCEPTIONS
        no_viewmaint_tool      = 1
        no_authority           = 2
        no_auth_for_sel        = 3
        data_access_restricted = 4
        no_functiongroup       = 5
        OTHERS                 = 6.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      FREE: lt_assign.
    ENDIF.

    SELECT * FROM zmm_ariba_ta_01 INTO TABLE lt_ta_01 WHERE action = '01'.
    SELECT * FROM zmm_ariba_ta_03 INTO TABLE lt_ta_03.
    SELECT * FROM zmm_ariba_ta_12 INTO TABLE lt_ta_12.
    SELECT * FROM zmm_consumos    INTO TABLE lt_consumos.

    IF gt_out IS NOT INITIAL.
      LOOP AT gt_out ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_out>).
        CALL FUNCTION 'CONVERSION_EXIT_MATN1_INPUT'
              EXPORTING
                input         = <ls_out>-matnr
              IMPORTING
                output        = <ls_out>-matnr.
      ENDLOOP.

      SELECT matnr matkl prdha
        INTO TABLE lt_matkl_prdha
        FROM mara
         FOR ALL ENTRIES IN gt_out
       WHERE matnr = gt_out-matnr.
    ENDIF.

    FREE: gt_post.
    LOOP AT gt_out INTO gs_out.
      MOVE-CORRESPONDING gs_out TO gs_post.
      gs_post-ernam = sy-uname.
      READ TABLE lt_assign WITH KEY werks = gs_post-werks
                           INTO ls_assign .
      IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_ta_01 WITH TABLE KEY bukrs = ls_assign-bukrs
                            INTO ls_ta_01.
        IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
          gs_post-bsart = ls_ta_01-bbsrt.
          READ TABLE lt_matkl_prdha WITH TABLE KEY matnr = gs_post-matnr
                                    INTO ls_matkl_prdha.
          IF sy-subrc = 0.
            READ TABLE lt_ta_12 WITH KEY bukrs = ls_assign-bukrs
                                         werks = gs_post-werks
                                         prodh = ls_matkl_prdha-prdha
                                INTO ls_ta_12.
            IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
              gs_post-knttp = ls_ta_12-knttp.
            ELSE.
              READ TABLE lt_ta_12 WITH KEY bukrs = ls_assign-bukrs
                                         prodh = ls_matkl_prdha-prdha
                                INTO ls_ta_12.
              IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
                gs_post-knttp = ls_ta_12-knttp.
              ENDIF.
            ENDIF.
            IF gs_post-knttp = 'K'.
              READ TABLE lt_consumos WITH KEY werks = gs_post-werks
                                              lgort = gs_post-lgort
                                     INTO ls_consumos.
              IF sy-subrc IS INITIAL.
                gs_post-kostl = ls_consumos-kostl_c.
              ENDIF.
              CLEAR gs_post-ekorg. " EXT_DMSF (30/09/02025)
              LOOP AT lt_ta_03 INTO ls_ta_03 WHERE werks = gs_post-werks
                                               AND lgort = gs_post-lgort
                                               AND low_id_cat <= ls_matkl_prdha-matkl
                                               AND high_id_cat >= ls_matkl_prdha-matkl.
                gs_post-ekorg = ls_ta_03-ekorg.
                gs_post-ekgrp = ls_ta_03-ekgrp.
                EXIT.
              ENDLOOP.
              IF gs_post-ekorg IS INITIAL.
                LOOP AT lt_ta_03 INTO ls_ta_03 WHERE werks = gs_post-werks
                                               AND low_id_cat <= ls_matkl_prdha-matkl
                                               AND high_id_cat >= ls_matkl_prdha-matkl.
                  gs_post-ekorg = ls_ta_03-ekorg.
                  gs_post-ekgrp = ls_ta_03-ekgrp.
                  EXIT.
                ENDLOOP.
              ENDIF.
            ENDIF.
          ENDIF.
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
      APPEND gs_post TO gt_post.
    ENDLOOP.

  ENDIF.

        prheaderx  = ls_prheaderx

      IMPORTING
        number     = lv_number

        pritem     = lt_pritem
        pritemx    = lt_pritemx
*       PRITEMEXP  =
        pritemsource = lt_itemsource
        praccount  = lt_praccount

      ADD 1 TO lv_posted.

ENDFORM.

This program significantly reduces manual effort, improves data quality, and ensures consistency when creating large volumes of Purchase Requisitions. If anyone has implemented similar tools or has suggestions for enhancements, I’d be happy to discuss ideas!

entry.title: Why Vectorized Master Data is Critical for AI on SAP ECC and S/4HANA
entry.content:
Why Most AI Agents Fail with SAP Data

AI Agents are rapidly becoming part of enterprise landscapes, and SAP ECC and S/4HANA are obvious targets for automation. However, what we see in the market today is concerning.

Most agentic solutions attempt to consume SAP data through custom coding. This approach creates three major problems:

  1. High development and maintenance costs

  2. Multiple, inefficient calls to the SAP backend

  3. Mass data extraction, where AI Agents pull entire tables just to find a few relevant records

In many of the solutions we reviewed, including agentic SDKs integrations such as Joule, n8n, ChatGPT, and Claude, AI Agents frequently fail, time out, or request all records from SAP ERP systems with minimal filtering. This is inefficient, risky, and completely unnecessary.

At Skybuffer AI, we believe there is a better way.

The Foundation: Preparing SAP Data for AI Consumption

Data preparation is the key to successful AI-driven automation. While topics like data silos and data quality are well known, they cannot be fully solved overnight. Instead of fighting this reality, Skybuffer AI introduces a simple and reliable data layer that AI Agents can consume efficiently.

Skybuffer AI uses SAP master data vectorization to enable fast, accurate access to SAP ECC and S/4HANA data from agentic workflows. Any SAP master data table, including views and CDS views, can be vectorized and materialized using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG).

Key capabilities include:

  • Support for full and delta loads

  • Near real-time synchronization with SAP

  • A scalable, AI-ready representation of SAP master data

 Pic. 1 Skybuffer AI – SAP Data Vectorization Configuration

Performance at Enterprise Scale

A common concern is performance. Vectorizing SAP master data row by row would indeed be slow, if done sequentially.

Skybuffer AI solves this with parallel embedding execution, allowing vectorization at enterprise scale. On servers with 8 GPUs, Skybuffer AI can process up to 1 million records in 30 minutes. That is scalable in case even faster vectorization solution is needed.

More importantly, once initial vectorization is complete, a self-healing delta mechanism ensures that only new or changed records are processed. This keeps the data current without impacting performance.

Business Value: Why This Approach Matters

The benefits are immediate and measurable:

  • No coding for intelligent master data search

  • No multiple calls to SAP backend systems

  • No full-table reads triggered by AI Agents

  • Faster, more reliable AI-driven processes

Consider a real-world scenario:
A vendor invoice arrives by email.

Pic. 2 Real Consumption-Based Invoice Example

The AI Agent reads the email and attachment, extracts the vendor name exactly as written on the invoice, and needs the corresponding SAP vendor number. Instead of querying SAP repeatedly or scanning entire tables, the Agent performs one single RAG search against vectorized SAP master data.

Within milliseconds, the correct vendor record is returned. It is accurate, up to date, and ready for posting in SAP.

Pic. 3 Skybuffer AI – Fast and Reliable SAP Data Search Using Data Vectorization

No coding. No overload. No hallucinations.

Applicable Across Many SAP Use Cases

The same approach works seamlessly across multiple scenarios, including:

  • Finding SAP users or business objects by name, email address, or other attributes

  • Creating Sales Orders in SAP from customer Purchase Orders

  • Resolving customer and material master data automatically

  • Creating Bills of Materials and routings from Excel files managed by R&D teams

  • Posting Service Entry Sheets

  • Rapidly enabling new use cases by simply nominating tables for vectorization

If the data exists in SAP, it can be prepared for AI consumption.

Built-In Authorization and Security

Security is not an afterthought.

Skybuffer AI applies the same concept used in AI assistants for Teams, Copilot, and Joule, so vectorized data accessed by users with an additional safeguard. Once the AI Agent selects relevant records via RAG, Skybuffer AI retrieves those records directly from SAP using SSO within the active conversation session, before providing data to the user.

This ensures:

  • Users only see data they are authorized to access in SAP

  • Vectorized data never bypasses SAP authorization rules

  • Enterprise-grade compliance and governance

Seamless Integration with Existing AI Agents

Already running AI Agents and just need access to SAP data?

Skybuffer AI provides an MCP Server, allowing your existing agentic solutions to consume vectorized SAP data without replacing your current platform. This makes Skybuffer AI an enabler, not a disruptor.

 Pic. 4 Skybuffer AI – MCP Server for Integration with Agentic SDK

Flexible Deployment: Cloud or On-Premise

Skybuffer AI is built on SAP HANA and can be deployed:

  • On-premise within your own infrastructure

  • In your SAP BTP tenant

A modern SAP UI5 user interface ensures an intuitive and productive user experience for both IT and business users.

Conclusion

SAP ECC and S/4HANA master data vectorization is the missing link between SAP and AI Agents.

With Skybuffer AI, enterprises can:

  • Eliminate coding

  • Avoid hallucinations

  • Reduce SAP backend load

  • Enable fast, secure, and reliable AI-driven processes

This is how SAP data becomes truly AI-ready.

entry.title: Tools in Service Transactions
entry.content:
You are a service manager

  • You create a service order to plan a service on customer site. 
  • You identify that this certain service can only be carried out using a specific tool such as a lifting platform.
  • You are wondering how you can use such tools in your service order.

Solution

  • In this blog I am going to explain how you can enable products as tools that can be used in service transactions.

 

Configurations in Customizing

Configurations are to be done that are are prerequisites for creation of products as tools.

Change Material Type FHMI

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Basic Settings -> Material Types -> Define Attributes of Material Types. 
  • You flag the checkbox for material type FHMI with description Production Resource/Tool and open the details.
  • You flag the checkbox Sales in the box User departments. (See screenshot in Figure 1.)  

Figure 1: Change view “Material types” for material type FHMI (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Change Screen Sequences

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Configuring the Material Master -> Define Structure of Data Screens for Each Screen Sequence.
  • In displayed view you select the checkbox for screen sequence 21 with description Std ind.(short) tab pages and double-click on Data screens on the left panel.
  • In displayed view you select the checkbox for screen sequence 21 and screen 17, then you double-click on Subscreens on the left panel.
  • In displayed view you change the program of screen sequence 21, screen 17, and subscreen 4 from SAPLMGD1 to SAPLCRMS4_PRUDUCT_SUBSCREEN. (See screenshot in Figure 2.)  

Figure 2: View Subscreens (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Maintain status for MARA-SRV_DURA and MARA-SRV_DURA_UOM

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
  • In displayed view search for field name MARA-SRV_DURA and double-click on this line so the view Field Groups is opened. In this view change the maintenance status from V to VF. (See screenshot in Figure 3.) 
  • You do the same for field name MARA-SRV_DURA_UOM.

Figure 3: View Field Groups for field name MARA-SRV_DURA (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Hide MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI for material type FHMI

Since the fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI are not relevant for tools used in service transactions, you can hide them for the field reference that is assigned to the material type FHMI.

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Logistics - General -> Material Master -> Field Selection -> Assign Fields to Field Selection Groups.
  • You choose a new field selection group for the two fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL (Response Profile) and MARA-SRV_SERWI (Service Profile) for instance you enter 211 as new selection group. 
  • You click on button Field Selection Maintenance at the end of the line so that the field selection group 211 is displayed.
  • Since these two fields MARA-SRV_ESCAL and MARA-SRV_SERWI are not relevant for tool items, you can hide them for the field reference that is assigned to the material type FHMI. For instance, you can set the radio button for Hide for field reference HALB that is assigned to the material type FHMI. (See screenshot in Figure 4.)

Figure 4: Example for hiding fields in selection group 211 (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Create a Product for Tools

  • You create a new product for material type FHMI (Production Resource/Tool), for instance SRV_TOOL (Service Tool) for industry sector M (Mechanical engineering).
  • As the configurations are done in customizing, you can maintain data in view Sales: sales org. 2 such as sales organization for instance 1710, distribution channel for instance 10, and item category group SRVT (Service Tool)
  • You can check view Prod.resouces/tools and maintain the work duration for this product.

Figure 5: Product Master view Prod.resources/tools of example product SRV_TOOL (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Controlling Integration

  • You open the following path in SAP Customizing Implementation Guide (SAP GUI transaction SPRO): Integration with Other SAP Components -> Customer Relationship Management -> Settings for Service Processing -> Controlling Integration -> Determine Cost Center and Activity Type for Tool.
  • You assign a cost center and an activity type to the created product SRV_TOOL. (See screenshot in Figure 6.)
  • As for service products, you maintain cost rates for respective cost center and activity type in SAP GUI transaction KP26 or open the following path in SAP Menu: Accounting -> Controlling -> Cost Center Accounting -> Planning ->Activity Output/Prices -> Change.

Figure 6: Example of cost center and activity type assignment to product SRV_TOOL (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Tool Items in Service Transactions

Now let’s process a tool item in service transactions. You can create a service quotation for a service and a tool that is required for execution of the service. (See screenshot in Figure 7.) 

Figure 7: Example of a service quotation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

The duration for the tool item is derived from product master data, in this example two hours. (See screenshot in Figure 8.) 

Figure 8: Example of a duration of a service quotation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

After accepting, a service order is created as follow-up. Of course, you can create a service order for a service and a tool directly. (See screenshot in Figure 9.) 

Figure 9: Example of a service order tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You enter the actual duration that is used for the tool. In this example three hours, see screenshot in Figure 10.

Figure 10: Example of a service confirmation tool item (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

You complete the service confirmation. For the service confirmation tool item, a controlling document is created to post actual cost. (See screenshot in Figure 11.) 

Figure 11: Example of a service confirmation (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

The actual duration was passed on as quantity to post the actual cost. You can check the quantity in app Service Actuals when item-based accounting is used. (See screenshot in Figure 12.) 

Figure 12: Service Actuals for a tool item when item-based accounting is used (screenshot from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025).

Conclusion

Hopefully after reading this blog post, you will have more in-depth knowledge about the enablement of tools and its process in service transactions.

Please don’t hesitate to raise your questions in Q&A forum of SAP Community or leave your comments below!

entry.title: Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond
entry.content:
Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond

Introduction

Over the last several years, I have been involved in multiple SAP AMS transitions following S/4HANA go-lives across different customer environments. While each program had its own complexity, one pattern consistently stood out: once the project teams exited, AMS struggled to keep pace with the new operational reality of S/4HANA and cloud-based landscapes.

In this blog, I am sharing what I have personally observed while leading SAP Basis and AMS delivery teams, why traditional AMS models struggle after S/4HANA go-live, and what has worked in practice to build a more future-ready SAP AMS operating model.

What I Observed When AMS Remained Reactive After S/4HANA Go-Live

In several programs I supported, AMS teams were structured around a traditional incident-driven model. This approach worked reasonably well in ECC environments, but in S/4HANA landscapes it quickly became unsustainable. Incident volumes increased, resolution cycles became longer, and teams spent most of their time reacting instead of stabilizing.

What I learned is that S/4HANA environments demand predictive operations, not reactive support. Teams that introduced proactive monitoring, early alerts, and preventive maintenance were able to reduce disruptions significantly. Where AMS remained reactive, instability persisted even months after go-live.

Why Automation Became Non-Negotiable in the AMS Programs I Managed

In the early phases of AMS onboarding, many operational tasks were still handled manually-user administration, system checks, transport validations, and log reviews. This consumed a large portion of the team’s capacity and left little time for root cause analysis or improvement initiatives.

Across the AMS programs I led, stability improved only after automation was treated as a foundation rather than an enhancement. Introducing automation across L1, L2, and L3 support reduced repetitive effort and improved consistency. More importantly, it allowed teams to shift focus from firefighting to continuous improvement and operational readiness.

Lessons Learned Managing AMS in Hybrid and Cloud Landscapes

As customers moved to hybrid and cloud-based SAP landscapes, AMS complexity increased noticeably. Issues were no longer limited to the SAP application layer but often involved hyperscaler platforms, network dependencies, security controls, and shared responsibility boundaries.

In these environments, AMS teams that lacked cloud operating maturity struggled with escalations and ownership clarity. What worked better was aligning AMS processes with cloud-native operations-integrating SAP Cloud ALM, using hyperscaler monitoring tools, and establishing clear governance for cost, capacity, and security. This alignment reduced friction between teams and improved overall predictability.

Applying SAP Activate Principles Beyond Implementation

While SAP Activate is widely used during implementation, I have seen real benefits when its principles are extended into AMS operations. In several engagements, AMS teams adopted fit-to-standard thinking, sprint-based enhancements, and controlled deployment cycles inspired by Activate.

This helped bring structure and transparency to post–go-live operations. Continuous testing automation, clearer documentation practices, and predictable release cycles made AMS more resilient and easier to manage, especially in fast-changing environments.

Moving Beyond SLA-Driven AMS Metrics

One recurring challenge I observed was the disconnect between AMS performance reports and business perception. AMS teams met SLAs, yet business stakeholders remained dissatisfied due to recurring disruptions during critical cycles.

The programs that performed better shifted focus from SLA-only metrics to business-oriented outcomes. Measuring system stability during month-end, process performance, reduction in disruptions, and user productivity provided a more accurate view of AMS effectiveness. This change also improved conversations with business stakeholders and built greater trust.

Building Resilience Into Everyday AMS Operations

With increasing cyber risks and compliance requirements, resilience became a key focus area in AMS delivery. In practice, this meant embedding disaster recovery readiness, high availability validations, security monitoring, and access reviews into regular operations rather than treating them as separate activities.

In the environments I worked with, automating parts of DR testing and security checks helped teams stay prepared without adding excessive manual effort. This approach significantly improved confidence during audits and critical business periods.

How AMS Roles Are Evolving in Practice

Another important shift I observed is the evolution of AMS skill requirements. Successful AMS teams today are no longer purely technical or functional. They combine SAP Basis knowledge with cloud, automation, security, and strong process understanding.

Teams that invested in cross-skilling especially in automation and observability, were better equipped to manage modern SAP landscapes. This shift also improved team engagement, as engineers moved from repetitive tasks to more value-driven work.

Key Takeaways

  • From my experience, reactive AMS models struggle to support modern S/4HANA landscapes
  • Automation must be treated as a foundation, not an optional improvement
  • Cloud-ready operating models are essential for hybrid and hyperscaler environments
  • Business-aligned metrics provide a more accurate measure of AMS success
  • Future-ready AMS teams require cross-skilled, automation-enabled resources

Conclusion

Based on my experience leading SAP AMS and Basis delivery teams, SAP AMS does not struggle because S/4HANA is unstable. It struggles when operating models fail to evolve with the platform. Organizations that design AMS around predictive operations, automation, cloud readiness, and business outcomes achieve faster stabilisation and stronger business confidence.

My key takeaway is simple: future-proofing SAP AMS is not about adding more processes or tools, but about applying practical experience, accountability, and continuous learning to how support is delivered.

Let’s Discuss

How has your SAP AMS model evolved after S/4HANA go-live? What changes made the biggest difference in improving stability and trust?

I look forward to learning from your experiences.

entry.title: High Impact SAP Data Objects to Clean for an S/4HANA Selective Transition from ECC
entry.content:
*Views Expressed here are my own and doesn't represent any entity.

Introduction

Moving from SAP ECC to S/4HANA using a Selective Data Transition is not just a technical system conversion,it is a data transformation journey. While selective carve outs allow organizations to migrate only relevant organizational units, time slices, or data sets, poor data quality can jeopardize the entire S/4HANA transformation.S/4HANA’s simplified data model, stricter checks, and real-time processing mean that legacy inconsistencies tolerated in ECC will cause errors, functional gaps, or performance issues in S/4HANA.

This blog outlines the SAP data objects that require mandatory data cleaning before a selective S/4HANA migration, along with practical examples and rationale for each.

Why Data Cleaning Is Mandatory in a Selective Transition

In a selective approach:

  • Only chosen company codes, plants, or years are migrated

  • Historical inconsistencies become more visible

  • Data is restructured, not simply converted

S/4HANA:

  • Enforces business partner (BP) as a single master

  • Removes many legacy tables

  • Uses real-time reconciliation

  • Requires consistent master and transactional data

Without cleaning, you risk:

  • Migration failures

  • Reconciliation mismatches

  • Broken business processes

  • Delayed go-lives

1. Business Partner (Customer & Vendor)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Duplicate customers/vendors

  • Inconsistent master data across company codes

  • Missing mandatory fields (address, tax, bank details)

  • Vendors acting as customers (and vice versa)

ECC Example

  • Vendor 100045 exists for AP

  • Customer 200078 exists for AR

  • Same legal entity, different tax IDs and addresses

Why This Is Mandatory

In S/4HANA:

  • Customers and Vendors are merged into Business Partner

  • Roles (Customer, Supplier) are assigned to a single BP number

  • Inconsistent data causes CVI (Customer Vendor Integration) errors

Rationale

Selective transitions often migrate only certain company codes, making duplicates harder to reconcile post-migration. Cleaning ensures:

  • Smooth BP conversion

  • Accurate AR/AP reporting

  • Compliance with S/4 data model

2. Material Master Data

What Needs Cleaning

  • Obsolete or unused materials

  • Incomplete views (MM, SD, PP)

  • Invalid units of measure

  • Duplicate material numbers

ECC Example

  • Material created but never used in 8 years

  • Sales view missing for materials with open SD history

  • Base UoM inconsistent with alternative UoM

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Performs real-time MRP

  • Uses simplified inventory tables (MATDOC)

  • Enforces stricter checks on material consistency

Rationale

Migrating unused or inconsistent materials:

  • Increases migration volume

  • Slows performance

  • Causes MRP and ATP errors

Selective transitions benefit most by reducing material footprint.

3. Chart of Accounts & G/L Accounts

What Needs Cleaning

  • Blocked or unused G/L accounts

  • Accounts without proper account type

  • Inconsistent descriptions across company codes

  • Legacy reconciliation accounts

ECC Example

  • G/L 799999 created for testing, never used

  • Same G/L has different names in different company codes

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Introduces Universal Journal (ACDOCA)

  • FI and CO are merged

  • Reconciliation accounts behave differently

Rationale

Dirty G/L data leads to:

  • Conversion errors

  • Financial reconciliation issues

  • Incorrect financial statements

In selective transitions, only active and relevant accounts should be migrated.

4. Open Financial Transactions (AR/AP)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Cleared documents not properly closed

  • Open items with incorrect statuses

  • Residual items with zero balance

  • Old parked documents

ECC Example

  • Invoice marked as open but cleared manually

  • Zero-balance open items still flagged as open

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Performs real-time reconciliation

  • No longer tolerates technical inconsistencies

  • Universal Journal requires exact balances

Rationale

Open AR/AP items are always migrated in selective scenarios. Incorrect open items cause:

  • Balance mismatches

  • Failed migrations

  • Post-go-live reconciliation chaos

5. Asset Accounting (FI-AA)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Assets without acquisition values

  • Assets without depreciation areas

  • Retired assets still marked as active

  • Incomplete asset master records

ECC Example

  • Asset created but never capitalized

  • Depreciation area missing for a company code

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Uses New Asset Accounting only

  • Fully integrated into Universal Journal

  • Legacy asset inconsistencies cannot be converted

Rationale

Selective transitions often migrate only active assets. Cleaning ensures:

  • Correct depreciation

  • Accurate asset balances

  • Compliance with S/4 FI-AA model

6. Open Logistics Transactions

What Needs Cleaning

  • Open purchase orders with no activity

  • Incomplete deliveries

  • Open production orders never closed

  • Inconsistent goods movements

ECC Example

  • PO created 6 years ago, no GR, no IR

  • Production order technically complete but not closed

Why This Is Mandatory

S/4HANA:

  • Uses MATDOC for inventory

  • Enforces strict document flow

  • Real-time stock valuation

Rationale

Open logistics documents are technically migrated, not recreated. Dirty data causes:

  • Stock inconsistencies

  • Migration failures

  • Incorrect inventory valuation

7. Customizing and Organizational Data

What Needs Cleaning

  • Unused plants, storage locations

  • Inactive company codes

  • Invalid assignments (plant to company code)

  • Legacy controlling areas

ECC Example

  • Plant exists but no postings in 10 years

  • Company code included but not in scope

Why This Is Mandatory

Selective transitions rely on precise scoping. Invalid org data:

  • Complicates data slicing

  • Causes migration logic conflicts

  • Increases testing effort

Rationale

Clean org structures ensure:

  • Correct selective extraction

  • Lean S/4 system

  • Lower total cost of ownership

8. Custom Code & Z-Objects (Indirect Data Impact)

What Needs Cleaning

  • Z-tables with obsolete data

  • Custom programs using removed tables

  • Hard-coded company codes or years

ECC Example

  • Z-table referencing BKPF/BSEG directly

  • Custom report using VBFA incorrectly

Why This Is Mandatory

While not migrated as data:

  • Custom code processes migrated data

  • Dirty Z-data can break business processes

Rationale

Selective data migration often includes selective Z-data. Cleaning avoids:

  • Runtime errors

  • Incorrect reporting

  • Post-go-live defects

Understand your Business "WHY" for DATA CLEARLY

A Selective S/4HANA transition magnifies data quality issues because only parts of the system are migrated. S/4HANA’s simplified architecture does not tolerate inconsistencies that ECC allowed for decades.

Mandatory Data Cleaning Ensures:

  • Successful migration runs

  • Accurate financial reconciliation

  • Stable business processes

  • Long-term S/4HANA performance

Key Takeaway:

Data cleansing is not a technical task—it is a business transformation enabler.
